DEPT is an Acronym for @milton_damian’s Double Empathy Problem Theory.

text:
I DO believe in neurodiversity in the general, and I also believe in supporting the needs of those of us with ADHD in all settings. 

But please if you are reading things I share on ADHD, just bear my viewpoint in mind. And feel free to ignore some/all of course.
user_description:
COVID Data Sharer and ADHD Twitterer

Likes: objective information, robust discussion and challenge.

Dislikes: offensiveness and rudeness

Trying to stay sane.

text:
Finally, I do not view ADHD as a neurodiversity.

That does NOT mean I don't utterly respect those who do. I just don't share the view. I, personally, very much view it as a disability.

This means I may accidentally offend those who do - and for that I am sorry. I try not to.

text:
Do you know where the term #Neurodiversity came from? Let’s start by breaking it down.
Neuro means “nerve”, “nervous system”.
Diversity refers to “various”, “several”.
The term was coined by sociologist Judy Singer, who is autistic & identifies as #Neurodivergent. https://t.co/JeTrBs5yNG

❓ What does Neurodivergent mean?

text: Got any questions about our position statement? It’s in a Word format to make commenting easier! Or want to join our Neurodiversity Team? Join us @FORRTproject! We are open to new collaborations, ideas and projects. Everyone is welcome! https://t.co/ZQxllIskz9

text: We also included a glossary of more than 30 key terms related to neurodiversity, Open Scholarship, social justice & Universal Design for Learning (e.g ableism, neuroqueer, identity first and participatory research)! With these in bold/italics in text at first mention in preprint. https://t.co/jJJ96nphOf
user_description: Integrating principles of open and reproducible scholarship into higher education and raising awareness of its pedagogical implications.

text: #Intersectionality should be considered in neurodiversity, Open Scholarship & social justice work. The intersectionality framework (e.g. Crenshaw) recognises the complexity of us existing in multiple overlapping identity spheres (e.g. race, (dis)ability, wealth, sexuality). https://t.co/JAKTf5uwn8
user_description: Integrating principles of open and reproducible scholarship into higher education and raising awareness of its pedagogical implications.

text: The social movement to promote #Neurodiversity shares similar core values to #OpenScholarship: accessibility, fairness, equity, diversity, and inclusion. Despite the overlap though there isn’t much ND representation within #OpenScholarship. We want to change that. https://t.co/uljt5IIw2R
user_description: Integrating principles of open and reproducible scholarship into higher education and raising awareness of its pedagogical implications.

text:
Why is #Neurodiversity important?
ND is rarely considered in justice, equality, or diversity. In academia ND is often the subject of research by NT researchers, raising questions of biased views and misunderstanding by NT researchers (e.g. Double Empathy Problem, @milton_damien).
user_description: Integrating principles of open and reproducible scholarship into higher education and raising awareness of its pedagogical implications.

text: #Neurodiversity includes neurotypical & neurodivergent people. A person is neurodivergent when their neurology diverges from the neurological majority. Examples of neurodivergence: dyslexia, dyspraxia, OCD/C, personality disorders/conditions, autism, ADHD/C, Tourette’s and tics. https://t.co/swgenhJ4i1
user_description: Integrating principles of open and reproducible scholarship into higher education and raising awareness of its pedagogical implications.

text:

text: Neurodiversity and neurodivergence are not interchangable. Neurodiversity is the spectrum of ALL human minds. Neurodivergence refers to difference from dominant societal concepts of “typical” neurocognitive functioning; usually resulting in challenges for the individual.

text:
@Unplanned_Rant This comes from the confusion between the words neurodiversity and neurodivergent.
A population is said neurodiverse when it contains individuals with different neurotypes, while an individual is called neurodivergent if it diverges from what has been (*) defined as the norm

text:
@OriginalCody82 @lgnrb .

"Neurodiversity" includes all brain types.

"Neurodivergent" = those who are not part of the majority neurotype (Neurotypical).

It includes ADHD, Dyslexia, Dyspraxia, Dyscalculia, Tourettes, & other brain types, as well as Autism.

Autism doesn't need a "cleaner" term.

.

text: @LunarRoot I was just trying to draw out the implicit argument if someone believes in neurodiversity without neurotypicality, like the person you quoted seems to.

@LunarRoot Maybe the idea here is of 'neurodiversity' as a wide range of different ways (and combinations of ways) of experiencing the world; there's not a single typical outlook from which people divert from, and there's no universal experience, only multiple overlapping experiences.

@PaulaMc007 @psychjoh @mencap_charity Don’t forget diagnostic overshadowing too. The amount of times I’ve heard my child’s pain being passed off as “a meltdown due to his autism” makes me incredibly mad… 😤 The system does not fit those with neurodiversity and needs drastic changes.
